title: B+LNZ Farming for Profit: Regenerative Agriculture in Your Farm System  Alister Moorhead

tasks.task: Conducting a field day discussion on pasture species selection and management.
subtasks: Explaining the purpose and setup of the diverse pasture project.
Discussing the selection of specific grass species (e.g., ryegrass, fescue, atom prairie grass) and their roles.
Covering legume species (e.g., red clover, lucerne, white clover) and their contributions to nitrogen cycling and forage quality.
Mentioning the use of cover crops (e.g., millet oats, rape, radish) and their functions.
Addressing potential issues with certain species (e.g., mustard, radish) and their impacts on future plantings and neighbors.
Discussing the importance of underground and above-ground development in pasture management.

tasks.task: Conduct a discussion on species selection for a diverse pasture.
Therefore, the relevant task would be the high-level MAINTASK with some subtasks related to the topics discussed.
Inspect a diverse pasture species trial.
Sow a diverse pasture mix following the specifications discussed.
subtasks: Plant ryegrass, fescues, prairie grass, clovers (red, white, lucerne), herbs (chicory, plantain), cover crops (millet oats, rape, radish), and include species like mustard, radish, and lotus.

tasks.task: Conduct a discussion on optimizing pasture diversity for agricultural profit.
subtasks: Explain the benefits of selecting specific grass species (e.g., ryegrass, fescues) and their roles in the pasture.
Describe the implementation of diverse legume species (e.g., red clover, lucerne) for nitrogen fixation and forage quality.
Discuss the use of cover crops and their functions during initial pasture sowing.
Address potential shortcomings and management strategies for species like mustard and radish that may hinder future pasture health.
